Award.AwardTitle: LIGO Observations and Gravitational Wave Astronomy
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award supports the goal of gravitational wave detection through the development and implementation of advanced analysis techniques needed by the advanced LIGO detectors. Specific analysis techniques being developed provide quantitative and physically meaningful measures of the odds that a given multi-detector gravitational wave data set includes the detector response to a gravitational wave burst; enable inference of the properties of an unanticipated gravitational wave source from its gravitational wave signal; and allow quantitative analyses to be carried out on data whose positional uncertainty includes a large fraction of the celestial sphere. Methods employed include Bayesian statistical analysis and model selection, Monte Carlo sampling and kernel density estimation methods, and the modeling of non-linear systems through finite non-linear networks.

Gravitational wave detection will mark the beginning of a new chapter in the annals of astronomy and astrophysics, and in our experimental understanding of gravity. Not since Galileo first turned a telescope to the heavens has the opportunity existed to view the cosmos in such a new and fundamentally different way. This work's goal is to enable gravitational wave detection using the LIGO detectors and exploit LIGO observations as a formidable new tool of astronomical discovery and a probe of fundamental physics. As a frontier of scientific discovery and accomplishment, the LIGO enterprise excites and motivates students to pursue careers in physics and astronomy, and captures the imagination and interest of the lay public. Through its direct contribution to that enterprise this has broad and historic impact. This project trains a postdoctoral scholar and a graduate student in frontier interdisciplinary science. The analysis methods developed under this award have applicability that extends beyond LIGO to other gravitational wave detection experiments (e.g., the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna or pulsar timing array observations), and beyond gravitational wave detection to other areas of science and beyond where inference need to be drawn on weak or poorly resolved signals (e.g., Auger cosmic-ray observations).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The principal goal of NSF Award 0969857, LIGO Observations and Gravitational Wave Astronomy,  was to support gravitational wave detection through the development and implementation of advanced analysis techniques that address as-yet unmet needs of the advanced LIGO detectors. Direct detection of gravitational waves would constitute a new test of our understanding of gravity. It would also be the first test of our understanding in the regime of strong (a million times stronger than those we experience on Earth) and dynamically self-sustaining fields. Work supported by this award led to the development of several new, state-of-the-art data analysis software tools, which can be used for LIGO data analysis, data analysis in other gravitational wave detection experiments, and data analyses in other fields. These include robust, Bayesian multi-detector analyses for the detection and characterization of periodic gravitational waves from binary systems of black holes or neutron stars, or bursts of gravitational waves from the coalescence of the same. Supporting software includes a modern, Markov Chain Monte Carlo package, a Matlab package for automatically tracking the correctness of units throughout complex calculations, and a Matlab package for data visualization on the sky.  Work supported by this award also led to a fundamentally new and powerful analysis of how gravitational wave detectors function, which has important implications for future detectors and detector designs, and important corrections to the literature on the sensitivity of gravitational wave detectors to cosmological gravitational wave sources. 
Beyond the direct applicadtion to gravitational wave detection with LIGO, work supported by this award has had both broad and specific influence on the development of pulsar timing as a technique for gravitational wave detection. The software developed under this award is all freely available on the web. The PI has also taken a leading role in advising local amateur astronomy organizations and participated in outreach activities that have reached the general public and the local and national amateur astronomer community.
